metadata.title: Extracting Use-of-Force Records from Vancouver Police PDF
metadata.description: This PDF contains detailed records of Vancouver Police's use-of-force incidents, provided after a public records request by journalists. Challenges include its very very very small font size and lots of empty whitespace.

cells.content:
# Extracting Use-of-Force Records from Vancouver Police PDF

This PDF contains detailed records of Vancouver Police's use-of-force incidents, provided after a public records request by journalists. Challenges include its very small font size and lots of empty whitespace.

from natural_pdf import PDF

pdf = PDF("use-of-force-raw.pdf")
page = pdf.pages[0]
page.show()

execution.output:
[DEBUG] Executing code: from natural_pdf import PDF
pdf = PDF('use-of-force-raw.pdf')
page = pdf.pages[0]...
[DEBUG] Evaluating expression: page.show()...

cells.content: Let's find all the headers, they're the text at the top of the pag, which means they have the smallest `y0`.

execution.output:
[DEBUG] Executing code: headers = page.find_all('text[y0=min()]')...
[DEBUG] Evaluating expression: headers.extract_each_text()...

result.data: ['OFFICER', 'DATE OF REPORT', 'DATE OF FORCE', 'TIME OF FORCE', 'PRECINCT', 'CASE #', 'SUBJECT PERSON', 'SEX', 'RACE', 'ETHNICITY', 'SUBJECT CONDITION LEADING TO FORCE', 'REASON FOR USE OF FORCE', 'OFFICER ACTIVITY PRIOR TO FORCE', 'SUBJECT WAS INJURED', 'OFFICER INJURIES', 'SUBJECT INJURIES', 'MENTAL HEALTH INDICATORS', 'FORCE OPTIONS ATTEMPTED', 'EFFECTIVE FORCE OPTIONS', 'TREATMENT RECEIVED OFFICER', 'TREATMENT RECEIVED SUBJECT', 'SUPERVISOR NOTIFIED', 'SUPERVISOR AT SCENE', 'SUPERVISOR NAME', 'CASE COUNT']

cells.content: We can now use those headers to create guides that fit between each column.

from natural_pdf.analyzers.guides import Guides

guides = Guides(page)
guides.vertical.from_headers(headers)
guides.show()

execution.output:
[DEBUG] Executing code: from natural_pdf.analyzers.guides import Guides
guides = Guides(page)
guides.vertical.from_headers(h...
[DEBUG] Evaluating expression: guides.show()...

cells.content: Once we've established the columns, we're free to extract the table. [pdfplumber](https://github.com/jsvine/pdfplumber) is smart enough behind the scenes to know what each row is.

298 rows × 25 columns

cells.content:
## Combining the results for every page

If you provide a list of pages, guides can extract the tables from each of them. It will also do nice things like automatically remove duplicate column headers without you even asking!

df = guides.extract_table(pdf.pages).to_df()
print("You found", len(df), "rows")

df.tail()

execution.output:
[DEBUG] Executing code: df = guides.extract_table(pdf.pages).to_df()
print('You found', len(df), 'rows')...
You found 970 rows
[DEBUG] Evaluating expression: df.tail()...
